title: Linear Approximation Function
text: Use the following equation L(x)=f(a)+f'(a)*(x - a) to make a linear approximation, where f(a) is the function and f'(a) is the derivative of the function.
speech: Use the following equation L(x)=f(a)+f'(a)*(x - a) to make a linear approximation, where f(a) is the function and f'(a) is the derivative of the function.
pacedSpeech: Use the following equation L(x)=f(a)+f'(a)*(x - a) to make a linear approximation, where f(a) is the function and f'(a) is the derivative of the function.

title: Plugging Into the Formula
text: $$\frac{\pi}{3}$$ rad is equivalent to 60°. Since we are looking for the linear approximation at $$x=\frac{\pi}{3}$$, the formula is given by $$L(x)=f{\left(\frac{\pi}{3}\right)}+\operatorname{f'}\left(\frac{\pi}{3}\right) \left(x-\frac{\pi}{3}\right)$$.

title: Solving for f(a) and f'(a)
text: Now, we must determine the values of f(a) and f'(a) to find L(x).

title: Determining f(a)

subHints.title: Plugging Into $$f{\left(\frac{\pi}{3}\right)}$$
subHints.text: $$f(x)=sin(x)$$ such that $$f{\left(\frac{\pi}{3}\right)}=sin\left(\frac{\pi}{3}\right)$$. What is $$sin\left(\frac{\pi}{3}\right)$$? Remember that $$x=cos(x)$$ and $$y=sin(x)$$.\n##figure1.gif##

title: Taking the Derivative of f(x)
text: The next step is finding f'(x) by taking the derivative of $$f(x)=sin(x)$$ where $$f'(x)=cos(x)$$.

text: Given that $$x=\frac{\pi}{3}$$ and $$f'(x)=cos(x)$$, what is f'(a)?

title: Putting it Together
text: Now that we have found the values of $$f{\left(\frac{\pi}{3}\right)}$$ and $$\operatorname{f'}\left(\frac{\pi}{3}\right)$$, we know that $$L(x)=\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}+\frac{1}{2} \left(x-\frac{\pi}{3}\right)$$.

title: Estimating sin(62°)
text: Solve for $$sin(62\degree)=f{\left(\frac{62\pi}{180}\right)}$$ ≈ $$L\left(\frac{62\pi}{180}\right)$$ where $$L(x)=\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}+\frac{1}{2} \left(x-\frac{\pi}{3}\right)$$. What is the approximation to estimate sin(62°)? Round your answer to five decimal places.
